words.def: Main article: Bill of lading
words.name: Bill of lading (BOL, BL, B/L)

words.def: Operating a tractor unit with no trailer attached.
words.name: Bobtailing

words.def: A person or company that arranges for the truck transportation of cargo belonging to others, using for-hire carriers to provide the actual truck transportation.[5]
words.name: Broker

words.def: Main article: Bulk cargo
words.name: Bulk cargo

words.def: See bulk cargo.
words.name: Bulk freight

words.def: See freight.
words.name: Cargo

words.def: Main article: Consignee
words.name: Consignee

words.def: Main article: Consignment
words.name: Consignment

words.def: Main article: Consignor
words.name: Consignor

words.def: Operating a truck empty.[8]
words.name: Deadheading

words.def: Main article: Electronic on-board recorder
words.name: Electronic on-board recorder (EOBR)

words.def: Main article: Float shifting
words.name: Float shifting

words.def: Main article: Freight
words.name: Freight

words.def: Main article: Dangerous goods
words.name: Hazardous materials (Haz-mat)

words.def: Main article: Intermodal freight transport
words.name: Intermodal

words.def: Main article: Just-in-time (business)
words.name: Just-in-time

words.def: Main article: Logbook
words.name: Log book

words.def: A document that describes the contents of a shipment in greater detail than a bill of lading. Commonly used as a checklist during unloading.[13][14]
words.name: Manifest

words.def: Motor carriers for-hire must apply for the authority to engage in interstate commerce with the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration.[5]
words.name: Operating authority

words.def: Main article: Oversize load
words.name: Oversize load

words.def: Main article: Pallet
words.name: Pallet

words.def: Consignee, importer, or buyer (who may or may not be the same) named in the bill of lading as the party responsible for receiving a shipment.[18]
words.name: Receiver

words.def: A consignor, exporter, or seller (who may or may not be the same) named in the bill of lading as the party responsible for initiating a shipment.[19]
words.name: Shipper

words.def: A dock or hub where freight originates, terminates, or is handled in the transportation process; or a location where motor carriers maintain operating facilities.[10]
words.name: Terminal

words.def: Main article: Tractor unit
words.name: Tractor

words.def: The capability to connect a truck to a land-based electric power supply ("Shore power") at a truck stop. Eliminates the need for engine idling while parked, and in the case of IdleAire, also supplies land-based climate control within the truck cab, as well as Internet and TV access.[20]
words.name: Truck Stop Electrification (TSE)

words.def: Main article: Common carrier
words.name: Common carrier

words.def: Employee of a carrier who is assigned to drive company-owned trucks.[22]
words.name: Company driver

words.def: A for-hire carrier contracted to one particular shipper. A contract carrier enters into a contract whose terms are negotiated between a specific carrier and specific customer.[5]
words.name: Contract carrier

words.def: A driver or carrier who transports cargo between regular, prescribed routes. Regular route drivers usually are at home on regular intervals, given the scheduled nature of their routes.[23][24][25]
words.name: Dedicated route

words.def: A licensed carrier that holds itself out to hire under either a public tariff for the general public (for-hire common carrier) or under a contract filed with a specific shipper (contract carrier). For-hire carriers must apply for operating authority with the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration.[5]
words.name: For-hire carrier

words.def: See over-the-road.
words.name: Irregular route

words.def: Main article: Less than truckload
words.name: Less-than-truckload (LTL)

words.def: See over-the-road.
words.name: Long-haul

words.def: A person or company providing transportation of property or passengers using commercial motor vehicles.[5]
words.name: Motor carrier

words.def: A driver or carrier who transports cargo to any place at any time, without prescribed schedules or routes. Long-Haul OTR involves being away for weeks, or months at a time, often cross-country or international (Canada and Mexico), given the unscheduled nature of their routes.[27]
words.name: Over-the-road (OTR)

words.def: Main article: Owner-operator
words.name: Owner-operator (O/O)

words.def: A not-for-hire carrier contracted to or owned by a shipper that does not offer services to the general public, and operates primarily to transport its own goods. Private carriers are not required to obtain operating authority by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration.[5][28]
words.name: Private carrier

words.def: A driver or carrier who transports cargo in a limited geographical area, usually within a certain radius of one's own home or company terminal, and may or may not maintain a schedule.[29]
words.name: Regional route

words.def: See dedicated route.
words.name: Regular route

words.def: A team of two or more drivers who ride together and drive the same truck in shifts, essentially allowing the truck to remain in motion almost constantly. Primarily used for time-sensitive freight.[8]
words.name: Team drivers

words.def: See semi-truck.
words.name: Big rig

words.def: See semi-truck.
words.name: Big truck

words.def: A tractor without a trailer.[8] In verb form, this also refers to operating a truck without a trailer.[30]
words.name: Bobtail

words.def: Main article: Cab over
words.name: Cab over

words.def: A vehicle composed of two or more separate units, a tractor (powered unit, semi-truck) and a trailer (unpowered unit, semi-trailer).[3]
words.name: Combination vehicle

words.def: Main article: Conventional truck
words.name: Conventional truck

words.def: A truck cab without a sleeper berth.[31]
words.name: Day cab

words.def: Main article: Dump truck
words.name: Dump truck

words.def: This term is derived from the number of tires that the typical OTR tractor-trailer configuration has. See also semi-truck.
words.name: Eighteen-wheeler

words.def: Main article: Semi-trailer truck
words.name: Semi-truck

words.def: A single vehicle, with no articulation. Normally 2 or 3 axles, sometimes with lift axles.
words.name: Straight truck

words.def: See semi-truck.
words.name: Tractor-trailer

words.def: A special truck (carrier) with a permanently mounted crane (upper). This design allows faster moves from site to site than conventional cranes.
words.name: Truck crane

words.def: A partition or separator within a liquid tank, used to inhibit the flow of fluids within the tank. During acceleration, turning, and braking, a large liquid-filled tank may produce unexpected forces on the vehicle due to the inertia of liquids.[3]
words.name: Baffle

words.def: A strong wall-like structure placed at the front of a flatbed trailer (or on the rear of the tractor) used to protect the driver against shifting cargo during a front-end collision. May also refer to any separator within a dry or liquid trailer (also called a baffle for liquid trailers) used to partition the load.[3]
words.name: Bulkhead

words.def: See sleeper berth.
words.name: Bunk

words.def: The interior of a truck where the driver sits to operate the vehicle.
words.name: Cab

words.def: See lift axle.
words.name: Cheater axle

words.def: A pair of tire and wheel assemblies mounted side-by-side on a single axle hub. In some applications it is replaced by a super single. On pickup trucks it is sometimes called a dually. The assembly has a greater load carrying ability as compared to a single wheel. It also provides redundancy so if one of the two tires fail the second will maintain support preventing loss of vehicle control and allowing the vehicle to travel to a repair facility.[32]
words.name: Dual wheels

words.def: Main article: Engine brake
words.name: Engine brake

words.def: Main article: Fifth wheel
words.name: Fifth wheel

words.def:
Main article: Gladhand connector
Interlocking connectors attached to air hoses that supply air from the tractor to the trailer for air brakes.[10]
words.name: Glad hands

words.def: See bulkhead.
words.name: Headache rack

words.def: Main article: Jake brake
words.name: Jake brake

words.def: A large pin, underneath the front of a trailer, which interlocks with the fifth wheel.[8]
words.name: Kingpin

words.def: A set of retractable, crank-up legs that support the front of a trailer when it is not connected to a tractor.[8]
words.name: Landing gear

words.def: An air-powered axle that may be raised or lowered to the ground to provide greater load-carrying capacity,[3] or to comply with axle weight requirements (see also Federal Gross Weight Bridge Formula).
words.name: Lift axle

words.def: Main article: Retarder (mechanical engineering)
words.name: Retarder

words.def:
Main article: Berth (sleeping)
The portion of the truck's interior designated for sleeping, legally must contain a bed.[34]
words.name: Sleeper berth

words.def: A single, larger wheel, substituted for a tandem assembly. The main benefit of a super single is a reduction in weight; combined with lower rolling resistance the super single promises better fuel economy. The disadvantage is the lack of tire redundancy from which tandem wheels benefit, as tire failure can disable the vehicle[32][35] and increased highway wear, through the high point loading and scrubbing of road surfaces when making tight turns[36]
words.name: Super single

words.def: A set of axles spaced close together, legally defined as more than 40 and less than 96 inches apart by the USDOT[37]
words.name: Tandem axle

words.def: A specialized trailer or truck/trailer combination used for transporting passenger vehicles.[38][39]
words.name: Auto transport

words.def: See bottom dump.
words.name: Belly dump

words.def: A trailer between 26 feet (7.9 m) and 29 feet (8.8 m) used primarily for the transport of beverages. Colloquially known as a sidebanger, sideloader, or route trailer.
words.name: Beverage trailer

words.def: A dump with a funnel-shaped floor for unloading through the bottom.[40]
words.name: Bottom dump

words.def: See livestock.
words.name: Bull wagon

words.def: See auto transport.
words.name: Car hauler

words.def: specially designed bulk dry van with open top for wood byproducts.
words.name: Chip van

words.def: Main article: Intermodal container
words.name: Container

words.def: A skeletal trailer composed of a simple chassis for the mounting of an intermodal container.[38]
words.name: Container skeletal carrier

words.def: A flatbed with specially fitted side plates and curved ribs supporting a tarp covering, commonly referred to as a "side kit". Named for the resemblance to horse-drawn covered wagons.[41][42]
words.name: Covered wagon

words.def: Can be either a dry box with tarp sides, or a flatbed with a movable frame of squared ribs supporting a tarp.[43]
words.name: Curtainside

words.def: A specialized dry van that maximizes interior space, with a lowered floor and higher roof. Normally used to transport bulky, relatively light cargo, such as furniture and electronics.[38]
words.name: Deep-drop van

words.def: A specialized trailer with 2 floors to allow for more cargo space.[44]
words.name: Double decker

words.def: A trailer between 26 feet (7.9 m) and 29 feet (8.8 m) long that can be used singularly as a delivery trailer in congested areas or in combination with another trailer for over the road.[10][45]
words.name: Doubles trailer

words.def: A flatbed with a lowered deck, featuring a raised step at the front, where the trailer attaches to the fifth wheel.[38]
words.name: Dropdeck

words.def: A variation of the liquid tank trailer, with a funnel-shaped bottom, used for hauling bulk quantities of dry powder (sometimes called bulk pneumatic). Usually loaded through holes in the top, unloaded through the bottom or through pneumatic force.[10][46]
words.name: Dry bulk

words.def: A simple, enclosed non-climate controlled rectangular trailer that carries general cargo, including food and other products that do not require refrigeration. Usually loaded/unloaded through the rear doors, requiring elevated access for forklifts to enter the trailer.[38]
words.name: Dry van

words.def: A bucket-like trailer with an open top for loading, commonly used for hauling bulk quantities of dirt, rock, gravel, etc. See dump truck.[47][48]
words.name: Dump

words.def: A flat trailer with no enclosure or doors. Can be loaded/unloaded from the sides or above, and does not require elevated access for forklifts.[38][41]
words.name: Flatbed

words.def: Main article: Lowboy (trailer)
words.name: Gooseneck lowboy

words.def: A rectangular enclosure with an open top for bulk loading, covered with a tarp, and a funnel shaped bottom for unloading grain, fertilizer, etc.[38]
words.name: Grain

words.def: See grain.
words.name: Hopper

words.def: A rectangular enclosure with sides featuring numerous ventilation holes, an interior with multiple levels, and usually a ramp in the rear for loading/unloading. Used for hauling cows, pigs, sheep, etc.[38]
words.name: Livestock

words.def: A dry van with solid or openable roof with a moveable mechanized floor for unloading.
words.name: Live-bottom

words.def: See timber.
words.name: Logger

words.def: See double dropdeck, or gooseneck lowboy.
words.name: Lowboy

words.def: See flatbed.
words.name: Platform

words.def: See auto transport.
words.name: Portable parking lot

words.def: A trailer between 26 feet (7.9 m) and 29 feet (8.8 m) long that can be used singularly as a delivery trailer in congested areas or in combination with another trailer for over the road.[10][45]
words.name: Pup

words.def: A dump with a rear pivot point allowing the front of the cargo area to be raised vertically for unloading through the rear.[51]
words.name: Rear dump

words.def: See refrigerated van.
words.name: Reefer

words.def: A refrigerated and insulated box trailer.[38]
words.name: Refrigerated van

words.def: See covered wagon.
words.name: Side kit

words.def: (aka Sidelifter) A specialized container trailer with cranes on the front and rear to allow for on-the-spot loading and unloading.[52]
words.name: Sideloader

words.def: See flatbed.
words.name: Skateboard

words.def: See dropdeck.
words.name: Stepdeck

words.def: Main article: Tank truck
words.name: Tank

words.def: See tank.
words.name: Tanker

words.def: A specialized trailer, used for transporting logs, consisting of a basic chassis with vertical stakes along the sides to hold the logs in place.[38] There are several types of timber trailers: Long wood trailers; Usually with four stakes, but can have more, evenly spaced for tree length logs to be carried longwise on the trailer; Short wood trailers, with two separated sets of four of stakes, commonly referred to as a double bunk,[53] and piggyback trailers. These trailers can be self loaded onto the back of a truck[54]
words.name: Timber

words.def: A special set-of-doubles: the second (usually shorter) trailer is hooked directly to the first via a fifth wheel on the rear of the first one (two semis).
words.name: 'B' train Double

words.def: A combination of a standard trailer and a shorter pup trailer. Legal in more than 20 states, use is usually restricted to toll roads, freeways, or by permit.[45]
words.name: Rocky Mountain Double (occasionally called an 'A' train)

words.def: A single trailer. Common dimensions range from 45 feet (14 m) to 53 feet (16 m) long, and up to 13.5 feet (4.1 m) tall.[45]
words.name: Standard

words.def: A combination of three pup trailers. Legal in 17 states, usually restricted to major highways, toll roads, or freeways.[45]
words.name: Triple

words.def: A combination of two standard trailers. Legal in 18 states, these unusually long combinations are usually restricted to toll roads or freeways.[45]
words.name: Turnpike Double
